      • quotedCommaSplit

      • permissiveQuotedCommaSplit

        @Deprecated
public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> permissiveQuotedCommaSplit(java.lang.String input)
        Deprecated. 

      • quotedSplit

        public static boolean quotedSplit(java.lang.String input,
                  char quoteChar,
                  char separatorChar,
                  boolean continued,
                  java.util.List<java.lang.String> previouslist)
        To better deal with newline characters in CSV files, The idea is that a line is parsed in multiple invocations like this: List row = new ArrayList(); boolean continued = false; do { String line = readLine(); if (line == null) break; // reached end-of-file. continued = quotedSplit (line, '"', ',', continued, row); } while (continued)

      • quotedSplit

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> quotedSplit(java.lang.String input,
                                           char quoteChar,
                                           char separatorChar)

      • quotedSplit

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> quotedSplit(java.lang.String input,
                                           char quoteChar,
                                           char separatorChar,
                                           boolean strictValidation)
        Efficiently parses strings like: a, b, c
        a,"b", c
        a,"b,b", c
        a,"b""b", c
        Also handles newline characters between quotes, assuming a multi-line string is passed as argument. If input is null, will return an empty list.
        Parameters:
        strictValidation - if you pass true, may throw an exception if the line doesn't adhere to CSV spec. If false, merely print a warning to STDERR.
        See Also:
        "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comma-separated_values"

      • emptyOrNull

public static boolean emptyOrNull(java.lang.String s)

      • urlEncode

        public static java.lang.String urlEncode(java.lang.String name)

      • stripTags

        public static java.lang.String stripTags(java.lang.String s)
        Strip html tags from a String. For example, abc<b>def will be turned into abcdef. Http entities such as &amp; are left unchanged, for doing that as well, see stripHtml.

public static java.lang.String join(java.lang.String sep,

        Join collection into a single string, with a separator between.

      • join

        @Deprecated
public static void join(java.lang.StringBuilder builder,
                   java.lang.String sep,
                   java.util.Collection<?> values)
        Deprecated. 
        Join collection into and append to a StringBuilder, with a separator between. Useful if you want to join strings and append to an existing StringBuilder.
        Parameters:
        builder - StringBuilder you want to append to. This variable will be modified.
        sep - Separator between strings
        values - collection of strings to join.

      • safeSplit

        public static java.lang.String[] safeSplit(java.lang.String regex,
                           java.lang.Object o)
        safely split a string, Unlike String.split(), this works on null strings. Returns a zero-length array if the input is null

        May return null, but will not throw an exception

        Compare two strings, without throwing nullpointerexception, ignoring case

      • initialUpper

        public static java.lang.String initialUpper(java.lang.String input)
        Make the first character in the String uppercase. Leave the remaining characters unchanged. Null-Safe: If the input value is null, this returns null;

      • toLowerCase

        public static java.lang.String toLowerCase(java.lang.String input)
        Null-Safe version of String.toLowerCase;

      • toUpperCase

        public static java.lang.String toUpperCase(java.lang.String input)
        Null-Safe version of String.toLowerCase;

      • toCamelCase

        public static java.lang.String toCamelCase(java.lang.String value)
        Remove spaces, make each word start with uppercase. CamelCase is a method for removing spaces from a phrase while maintaining leglibility. For example "Small molecule" -> "SmallMolecule" "Show me your ID!" -> "ShowMeYourID!" "Two spaces" -> "TwoSpaces" " surrounded " -> "Surrounded" Null-Safe: returns null if input is null;

      • scientificShort

        public static java.lang.String scientificShort(java.lang.String species)
        //TODO: this is bioinformatics, may be moved to a different class Shorten a scientific species name. Takes the first capital letter of the first word, plus the second word. Homo sapiens -> Hsapiens

      • escapeMysqlLiteral

        public static java.lang.String escapeMysqlLiteral(java.lang.String literal)
        Applies escaping as described in MySQL documentation here: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/string-literals.html Note that this applies escapes for a literal enclosed by single quotes, not double quotes!
